title: Huawei CFO heads back to Vancouver court over U.S. allegations of sanctions violation and trade-secret theft
text:
The chief financial officer of Chinese telecom giant Huawei will return to court Monday in Vancouver, in a case that will determine whether she is extradited to the United States.

Meng Wenzhou’s arrest in December by Canadian authorities threw the three countries involved into diplomatic chaos. Soon after her detainment, China arrested two Canadians — including a former diplomat — on espionage charges.

The U.S. says Meng and Huawei — which was founded by her father, Ren Zhengfei — are guilty of violating sanctions against Iran, a charge Meng and the Chinese government adamantly deny.

See: How to invest in — or avoid — what makes China, China

On Monday, Meng’s lawyers are expected to argue that her detainment at Vancouver International Airport on Dec. 1 was unlawful and that the case should be delayed or thrown out. Video of Meng’s arrest at the airport was released last month by the Supreme Court of British Columbia, but additional audio and video evidence is expected to be discussed at the hearing — particularly her interview immediately after detainment.

Getty A scene from the Huawei celebration of its launch of the Huawei P30 Pro phone in London.

The case has been closely watched by Washington, Ottawa and Beijing. Huawei is one of China’s largest private companies, and the U.S. and other countries have sought to ban the use of its telecom equipment within their borders, arguing that it has dangerously close relations with the Chinese government and military.

Huawei has long said the Meng case was “guided by political considerations and tactics, not by the rule of law,” a claim that was bolstered after President Donald Trump said the charges could be dropped if that might benefit U.S. trade talks with China. But experts said this week’s proceedings are likely to focus on whether Canadian authorities unlawfully detained Meng.

The resumption of the case comes just one month before Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces a tough re-election bid in October. His Liberal Party has gradually slipped in polling and is at risk of losing its majority to the Conservative Party, led by Andrew Scheer.

Domestic issues like affordable housing and income equality remain key issues in the election.

But Canada’s relationship with China looms large as an economic and political concern for voters. China is Canada’s second largest trading partner, a relationship that was further strained when China held up the import of Canadian soybeans, pork and canola earlier this year — a move widely interpreted as retaliation for Meng’s arrest.

Conservative challenger Scheer took the opportunity to place blame on Trudeau, telling him that “Canada is being bullied by the Chinese government, and you have done nothing to stand up for Canada in response.”

Bloomberg Meng Wanzhou.

The neck-and-neck race means that the Meng case could have an outsized impact on voters’ decisions. Taking what is perceived as a soft line against China has become a political liability in Canada, as polling has shown increasing rejection of closer ties with China and overwhelming approval of Meng’s arrest.

Tanner Brown is director of real-time news at Caixin Global in Beijing.
description: Meng Wenzhou’s lawyers will seek a stay in case that could extradite her to the U.S.
